article:
Japanese high school students do not drive cars. Many of them either walk   _  ride bicycles if the distance is not too great. In other   _  , a lot of students have to  _  public
buses and trains, often changing lines several times in order to reach their  _  . It is common for some students to  _  two
or more hours each day on  _  transportation. After junior high school, students attend schools based   _  standardized high school entrance examination scores. As a result, some students travel a great distance to   _  the school. The school day begins at 8:30, so students may leave home  as early as  6:30. While some students sleep or study during their long travel, public transportation also  _   a chance for socializing with peers . Students   on the way  to school are regulated by school policies. These policies may prohibit    _  activities in
public-- chewing gum, consuming snacks,   _  books
while walking-- anything that might reflect   _  on the reputation of the school. Each school has a unique   _  that makes its students easily identifiable to  the public  . School policies often require students to   _  on buses and trains,  _  seats open for other
passengers in order to show thoughtfulness towards others. In practice,  _  , students tend to relax  _  they
move farther away from school.
